content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and changes the basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, by specifying credible sources for specific information and changing "may have" to "has" in subsections (a) and (c)(1). Subsection (d) is also amended. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" specifies credible sources for specific information and changes "may have" to "has" in subsections (a) and (c)(1). Subsection (d) is also amended to set a 15-day time period for determining the need for a preliminary investigation by the Attorney General. The Attorney General must decide within 15 days whether there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law. If there is insufficient evidence, the matter is closed. If there is enough evidence, a preliminary investigation is initiated. If the Attorney General cannot determine within 15 days, the matter is closed at the end of the period. The Attorney General must decide within 15 days if there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law. If unable to determine, a preliminary investigation is initiated with specific information from a credible source. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Prosecutorial jurisdiction under title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify limitations to alleged criminal law violations and related matters when appointing an independent counsel. The appointment of an independent counsel is requested by the Attorney General to fully investigate and prosecute alleged criminal law violations and related matters. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of the independent counsel is defined to ensure adequate authority for the investigation and prosecution. The independent counsel is appointed by the Attorney General to investigate and prosecute alleged criminal law violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. The prosecutorial jurisdiction is defined to ensure adequate authority for the investigation and prosecution. Authorities and duties of independent counsel are outlined in Section 5. The independent counsel is provided with office space within a Federal building by the Administrator of General Services, unless other arrangements are more cost-effective. Amendments ensure compliance with Department of Justice policies by requiring adherence to policies at all times. Amendments to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code require adherence to Department of Justice policies at all times, including the enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information relating to criminal proceedings. Prior amendments made in 1994 are repealed. The amendments made to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code in 1994 are repealed. A limitation on expenditures for independent counsel offices is imposed, restricting funds after a 2-year period unless specified in a later appropriations Act. Limitation on expenditures for independent counsel offices: No funds can be used for office operation after 2 years unless specified in a later appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies or specific sections. Section 596(b)(2) is also amended to give the court division the authority to terminate an independent counsel's office at any time. The court division has the authority to terminate an office of independent counsel at any time, either on its own motion, upon the request of the Attorney General, or upon the petition of the subject of an investigation conducted by the independent counsel. This can happen if the investigation is completed or substantially finished, and the petition is made more than 2 years after the appointment of the independent counsel. The petition can be made more than 2 years after the appointment of the independent counsel, stating that the investigation is completed or substantially completed. It suggests that the Department of Justice should take over the investigation or prosecution if it's in the public interest. The independent counsel must report monthly expenditures to specified committees. The amendment will take effect after the first month following the enactment of the Act. The amendment requires the independent counsel to report monthly expenditures to designated committees. Additionally, there is a provision for periodic reappointment of the independent counsel every two years. The amendment mandates monthly expenditure reports by the independent counsel and requires reappointment every two years. The independent counsel should be terminated if not reappointed by the court within 90 days after the end of the 2-year period. If reappointment is necessary, the court will appoint the applicant or another qualified person. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, with recommendations to enhance cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
